newsitem.title: INDIA: Bombay shares end mixed, Reliance gains 2.35 pct.
newsitem.headline: Bombay shares end mixed, Reliance gains 2.35 pct.

text.p: Shares at Bombay bourses ended Tuesday little changed from their previous close and near the day's lowest levels, indicating a weak market undertone, traders said.
Petrochemical major Reliance Industries rose 6.0 rupees, or 2.35 percent, to 261.75 rupees, above the intra-day low of 253.75, on renewed speculative purchases, they said.

After a weak start, the Bombay Stock Exchange's (BSE) benchmark 30-share index surged nearly 1.25 percent in mid-session on buying support before dropping on profit-taking to end with a net loss of 3.20 points, or 0.10 percent, over Monday's close.
"I guess people wanted to square off oustanding positions. The market mood still remains confused," said Piyush Vora, a member-broker of the BSE.

The government on Tuesday gave its economy mixed grades and said more free-market reforms were needed to compete with developing powerhouses like China. Releasing the annual Economic Survey, the government said infrastructure bottlenecks, rising inflation and sluggish exports clouded a seven percent average annual growth rate which placed India among the top 10 economic performers in the world.

Market participants said speculation ahead of the budget led to choppy trading. "There is a lot of uncertainty about what the budget would contain. There are too many constraints on the government," said Sanjay Vaid, chief dealer at local firm Lloyds Securities.
Finance Minister P. Chidambaram presents the 1997/98 budget (April-March) on Friday.
Dealers said foreign funds mostly stayed on the sidelines, with local speculators dictating price trends. SBI rose 0.50 rupees to 274.0, but ITC was down 5.50 to 388.75.
